lines.line_text: I Lang hae thought, my youthfu' friend,
A Something to have sent you,
Tho' it should serve nae other end
But how the subject theme may gang,
Perhaps it may turn out a Sang;
Ye'll try the world soon my lad,
Ye'll find mankind an unco squad,
And muckle they may grieve ye:
For care and trouble set your thought,
And a' your views may come to nought:

stanzas.stanza_text:
Ye'll try the world soon my lad,
And ANDREW dear believe me,
Ye'll find mankind an unco squad,
And muckle they may grieve ye:
For care and trouble set your thought,
Ev'n when your end's attained;
And a' your views may come to nought:
Where ev'ry nerve is strained.

lines.line_text: I'll no say, men are villains a';
Wha hae nae check but human law,
But Och, mankind are unco weak,
If Self the wavering balance shake,

stanzas.stanza_text:
I'll no say, men are villains a';
The real, harden'd wicked,
Wha hae nae check but human law,
Are to a few restricked:
But Och, mankind are unco weak,
An' little to be trusted;
If Self the wavering balance shake,
It's rarely right adjusted!

lines.line_text: Yet they wha fa' in Fortune's strife,
Their fate we should na censure,
For still th' important end of life,
A man may hae an honest heart,
A man may tak a neebor's part,
Yet hae nae cash to spare him.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Yet they wha fa' in Fortune's strife,
Their fate we should na censure,
For still th' important end of life,
They equally may answer:
A man may hae an honest heart,
Tho' Poortith hourly stare him;
A man may tak a neebor's part,
Yet hae nae cash to spare him.

lines.line_text: Ay free, aff han', your story tell,
But still keep something to yoursel
Conceal yoursel as weel's ye can
But keek thro' ev'ry other man,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Ay free, aff han', your story tell,
When wi' a bosom crony;
But still keep something to yoursel
Ye scarcely tell to ony.
Conceal yoursel as weel's ye can
Frae critical dissection;
But keek thro' ev'ry other man,
Wi' sharpen'd, sly inspection.

lines.line_text: The sacred lowe o' weel plac'd love,
I wave the quantum o' the sin;
But Och! it hardens a' within,
To catch Dame Fortune's golden smile,
And gather gear by ev'ry wile,
Not for to hide it in a hedge,

stanzas.stanza_text:
To catch Dame Fortune's golden smile,
Assiduous wait upon her;
And gather gear by ev'ry wile,
That's justify'd by Honor:
Not for to hide it in a hedge,
Nor for a train-attendant;
But for the glorious priviledge
Of being independant.

lines.line_text: The fear o' Hell's a hangman's whip,
To haud the wretch in order;
But where ye feel your Honor grip,
Let that ay be your border:

stanzas.stanza_text:
The fear o' Hell's a hangman's whip,
To haud the wretch in order;
But where ye feel your Honor grip,
Let that ay be your border:
It's slightest touches, instant pause 
Debar a' side-pretences;
And resolutely keep it's laws,
Uncaring consequences.

lines.line_text: But still the preaching cant forbear,
Yet ne'er with Wits prophane to range,

stanzas.stanza_text:
The great CREATOR to revere,
Must sure become the Creature;
But still the preaching cant forbear,
And ev'n the rigid feature:
Yet ne'er with Wits prophane to range,
Be complaisance extended;
An athiest-laugh's a poor exchange
For Deity offended!

lines.line_text: When ranting round in Pleasure's ring,
Or if she gie a random-sting,
But when on Life we're tempest-driven,

stanzas.stanza_text:
When ranting round in Pleasure's ring,
Religion may be blinded;
Or if she gie a random-sting,
It may be little minded;
But when on Life we're tempest-driven,
A Conscience but a canker 
A correspondence fix'd wi' Heav'n,
Is sure a noble anchor!

lines.line_text: Your heart can ne'er be wanting!
In ploughman phrase 'GOD send you speed,'
And may ye better reck the rede,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Adieu, dear, amiable Youth!
Your heart can ne'er be wanting!
May Prudence, Fortitude and Truth
Erect your brow undaunting!
In ploughman phrase 'GOD send you speed,'
Still daily to grow wiser;
And may ye better reck the rede,
Than ever did th' Adviser!
